extracted_facts.section: Difference in Treatment Outcome in Outpatients With Anxious Versus Nonanxious Depression: A STAR*D Report
extracted_facts.span: A total of 2,876 adult outpatients with major depressive disorder, enrolled from 18 primary and 23 psychiatric care sites, received citalopram in Level 1 of STAR*D.
The aim of citalopram treatment in Level 1 was to achieve symptom remission, which was defined as QIDS-C score â‰¤ 5.
The primary outcome measure was the HAM-D score, obtained by research outcome assessors using telephone-based structured interviews at entry and exit from citalopram treatment.

extracted_facts.effect_size: lower remission rates compared to nonanxious depression
extracted_facts.span: patients with anxious depression were less likely to respond or to remit with citalopram treatment than those with nonanxious depression

Ms. D was started on a course of antidepressant therapy with citalopram... After 6 weeks of combined treatment with citalopram and a benzodiazepine, Ms. D reported a significant improvement in all her symptoms, and remission was achieved at the end of the 10th week of treatment.
a benzodiazepine was prescribed, which brought about a significant improvement in her insomnia and agitation.
